Anhydrous Ammonia System

Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary



















March 2014



 

ANHYDROUS AMMONIA SYSTEM

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





1    Chemical Accident Prevention and Emergency Response Policy



It is the policy of the BASF Corporation Attapulgus Operations (BASF) facility management to implement the requirements of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) in accordance with the EPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68.  BASF's objective is to minimize the risk of a release of anhydrous ammonia (ammonia) and, if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to BASF's employees, the public, and the environment. This objective will be accomplished by utilizing general good operating practices, providing appropriate training to all employees, complying with pertinent codes and regulations, and proactively planning and coordinating emergency response activities with BASF's local emergency response providers.



BASF's management is committed to providing the resources necessary to implement this policy.



2    Facility Description



BASF manufactures petroleum catalysts, including fluid cracking and moving bed catalysts, for sale to oil refineries.  As part of this process, BASF uses ammonia for pH control in various applications in sufficient quantities to be subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions. The Attapulgus Site has one 12,000-gal ammonia storage tank.  



3    General Chemical Accident Prevention Program and Ammonia-Specific Prevention Steps



BASF is governed by a set of OSHA and EPA (and corresponding Georgia) regulations that require a number of activities intended to prevent a release of hazardous materials, or if a release inadvertently occurs, to minimize the consequences of a release to the facility's employees, the public, and the environment. Some of these OSHA and EPA regulations include:



    29 C

FR Part 1910.120, 1910.38, 1910.165  OSHA Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response, Employee Emergency Plans and Fire Prevention Plans, and Employee Alarm Systems, respectively

    40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions

    40 CFR Part 110, Discharge of Oil

    40 CFR Part 112, Oil Pollution Prevention

    40 CFR Part 117, Determination of Reportable Quantities for Hazardous Substances

    40 CFR Part 122, EPA-Administered Permit Programs: The National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System 

    40 CFR Part 262,  Standards Applicable to Generators of Hazardous Waste

    40 CFR Part 302, Designation, Notification, and Reportable Quantities

    40 CFR Part 355, Emergency Planning and Notification



In particular, BASF has instituted an ammonia-specific accident prevention program in conformance with the provisions of 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, and Georgia's Rules of Safety Fire Commissioner Chapter 120-3-12, Rules and Regulations for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.  Key concepts of this program include periodic Process Hazard Analyses (PHA), up-to-date operations and maintenance procedures and training, Management of Change and Pre-Startup Review processes, periodic compliance audits and incident investigations, and employee participation in site safety processes.



3.1    Process Hazard Analyses



A multi-departmental team of BASF employees recently conducted an ammonia system Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) in October 2012 using current Process Safety Information.  The PHA was designed to proactively identify and address any system weaknesses in order to prevent accidental ammonia releases.  Items identified were documented and appropriate work orders submitted.  Procedures are in place to maintain this PHA consistent with the current ammonia process and to update and revalidate it at least every five years.



3.2    Procedures and Training



It is the Attapulgus Site's policy to ensure that its employees are provi

ded clear instructions for safely conducting all work-related activities.  Accordingly, the ammonia system has a set of related standard operating procedures (SOPs) and safe work practices.  Employees operating the ammonia system receive various forms of training in these SOPs and safe work practices to ensure that they have the knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out their duties.



It is also the site's policy to inspect, test, and maintain its process equipment in a manner consistent with applicable manufacturer's recommendations and recognized good engineering practices.  Accordingly, BASF has ammonia-related maintenance procedures addressing preventative maintenance and repairs, hot work permits, etc designed to prevent accidental ammonia releases.  Maintenance mechanics and technicians receive appropriate training in these procedures to ensure that they have the knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out their duties.  In addition, the Attapulgus Site works with its maintenance contractors to ensure that they are familiar with and meet or exceed all site safety standards and practices.



3.3    Management of Change and Pre-Startup Review Processes



BASF management recognizes that processes and equipment constantly change.  To ensure that these changes are managed and implemented safely, BASF has Management of Change and Pre-Startup Review processes in place to ensure that safety and health considerations and procedural and training requirements are addressed in conjunction with any change being implemented.



3.4    Compliance Audits and Incident Investigations



BASF conducts routine audits of its ammonia accident prevention program to ensure the program's effectiveness and continuous improvement.  However, should an ammonia release occur, BASF has an Incident Investigation process designed to quickly identify root causes and appropriate actions to prevent future releases.  These investigations are reviewed regularly for trends, etc as

a means of further managing the safety of BASF's manufacturing processes.



3.5    Employee Participation 



BASF's ultimate goal is to achieve an injury-free workplace.  An ongoing objective in support of this goal is to include all employees in all facets of safety.  Participation in site safety efforts is therefore expected and rewarded.  Employees participate in various safety processes such as Workplace Inspections, Behavioral Safety Observations, Job Safety Analyses, Root Cause Analyses, Process Hazard Analysis, etc.



4    Five Year Accident History



BASF has had no releases of ammonia that have affected onsite personnel, the public, or the environment in the past five years.



5    Emergency Response Program



BASF does have an onsite emergency response capability to respond to an ammonia-related emergency. Therefore, BASF trained personnel will serve as first responders  and will contact offsite emergency responders, Decatur County Emergency Management Agency and Decatur County Fire Department, for assistance in the event of an ammonia-related emergency. 



In the event of a non-emergency ammonia release, BASF employees trained in the safe operation of the ammonia system will close automatic and manual shutoff valves to terminate the flow of ammonia.  



6    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



BASF has made the following improvements to the safety of its ammonia system, 



    Installed a deluge suppression system with leak detection

    Installed hydrostatic vents between block valves.

Planned improvements include:

The installalation additional ammonia monitors in the process area.

The installalation of improved tank content monitoring instrumentation.
